title: Jameela Jamil reveals she battled cancer twice as she hits back at Twitter trolls over dress
text:
Jameela Jamil has revealed that she had cancer twice as she hit back at a cruel troll on Twitter who said she was 'too old' to dress a certain way.

The striking actress said that having cancer has made her grateful to get older as she slammed the author of the tweet for being 'ageist.'

The comment came after Jameela shared a picture of herself wearing a floral dress, and the troll responded: 'You are too old to dress like that. Not a good look'.

Brave: Jameela Jamil took to Twitter on Monday and wrote she has battled cancer TWICE and feels privileged to get older, after an 'ageist' troll told her she was too old to wear this dress

Jameela first wore the dress at the end of September outside Build Studios in New York following the conclusion of the fourth and final series of The Good Place.

The gown had featured huge puff sleeves and with an off-the-shoulder neckline and was covered in a stunning floral pattern.

Hitting back in a series of tweets, Jameela said the 'biggest nonsense' always comes from men and that they were the 'majority of people who say dumb s*** to me.'

She then revealed that she had suffered from cancer on two occasions.

Bright: The striking actress, 33, first wore the dress at the end of last month when chatting with fans at Build Studios in New York following the conclusion of the final series of The Good Place

She wrote: 'I would just like to say, that as someone who has been chronically ill my whole life, and had cancer twice, I find it EXTREMELY offensive that there is a cultural taboo around aging.

'Those of us who fight for our lives and those who lost that fight young, deserve more respect.'

The star also suffers from a coeliac disease and severe food allergies and her spine was damaged when she was hit by a car when she was 17.

Nasty: When the troll responded with the unkind comments, she wrote: 'The biggest nonsense always comes from men in my mentions'

Jameela, who stars as Tahani Al-Jamil on NBC's hit comedy series, had previously revealed in 2015 that she had suffered a breast cancer scare following the discovery of a lump which later turned not to be cancerous.

The troll had hit out at the star after she posted a clip of her September appearance on Noah's hit show.

In the video she explained her dislike of 'cancel culture'.

When the troll responded with the unkind comments, she wrote: 'The biggest nonsense always comes from men in my mentions.

'I like men. I know wonderful men. I’m not saying all men are like this.

Still angry: The star later added that 'It is a sickness of our society to look at aging as anything other than an achievement/privilege'

'But some men are not doing the rest of you favours on this app. They are currently the vast majority of the people who say dumb s*** to me.'

In further tweets, the 5ft 11in beauty appeared to respond to another comment, which has since been deleted.

She wrote: 'That’s fine. I don’t care if you think I’m 78. Because I think aging is cool and I hope I’m lucky enough to be able to do that.

'Not everyone gets the luxury of getting older. And I think it’s a sacred thing that I cherish every day. My lines are my souvenirs.'

She later added: 'It is a sickness of our society to look at aging as anything other than an achievement/privilege.'

Jameela has long spoken out in support of body confidence, and recently said she is 'thankful' for the physique she has.

She told InStyle magazine: 'Instead of practising body positivity, I practice body neutrality...I constantly thank my body for what it does for me.

'I think about how it heals and repairs itself, takes me from point A to B, and allows me to do my job, have sex, and just live my life. It’s a finely tuned engine that deserves to be respected, and I’m so grateful for it now

'Stop shaming people about their body, stop shaming people about their age, stop shaming people about their symmetry. Just let a b***h live.'

The former BBC radio presenter added that celebrities have a responsibility to be good role models and set a good example for young people.

She told how she feels celebrities have replaced religion for a lot of people and young people sometimes listen to them more than they do their parents or teachers.

Jameela is in a relationship with James Blake who she said empowers her and helps teach her to 'stick up for herself'.
